utterances: Thank you very much.
Bye-bye.
Thanks for the call.
And let's see if we can go now to - this is Linda(ph), Linda with us from Iowa City.
Hi.
Hi.
And you don't have to go very far to campaign…
Oh, I don't have to go very far.
And I - it turns out I have a lot in common with your young reporter because I do started out campaigning for people when I was even younger than 9.
I trembled up and down the street with my little wagon with campaign things for Eisenhower.
Well, please tell me it was a radio flyer.
It was.
(Soundbite of laughter)
My little red wagon.
And I - then like Hillary, I turned against those of Republican Party and the Vietnam War when I was in college and became a Democrat because of issues like poverty and children issues.
And - then campaigned for George McGovern.
George McGovern there in Iowa in 1972.
Yup.
And…
My husband and I both campaigned for him, while Bill and Hillary were campaigning for him in Texas.
Mm-hmm.
Ken Rudin, that's the campaign you say where the Iowa caucuses really took off.
Well, actually, it didn't take off, but George McGovern was the first one who recognized that there was such a thing as the Iowa caucuses, that was an early event.
And under the radar, George McGovern went into Iowa and didn't win.
I mean, he finished, actually, uncommitted one and that Ed Muskie the Democratic frontrunner.
But McGovern did much better than anybody expected.
And Jimmy Carter was well aware of McGovern's strategy.
And four years later, in 1976, he is the one who made Iowa the staple as it is now in presidential politics.
Mm-hmm.
And we won our precinct by one vote, the one I was campaigning in Election Day.
I got two people to the polls 15 minutes before it closed, and we won the precinct by one vote.
Congratulations.
That's nice work.
And right now, I'm campaigning for Hillary.
Well, good luck to you, too.
Thank you.
And thanks very much for the call.
We're talking with our political junkie, Ken Rudin.
You can read his Political Junkie column at our Web site, that's at npr.org, and join us every Wednesday as Ken joins us up until Election Day and probably thereafter.
If you'd like to join the conversation: 800-989-8255.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
And this is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And let's see if we can get another caller in.
And this is John(ph), John with us from Shreveport in Illinois, calling with an answer on the trivia question.
Good afternoon.
Afternoon.
We already know that Jimmy Breslin was Norman Mailer's running mate for mayor in New York City in 1969.
What was their slogan?
Vote the rascals in.
Aha.
That may have been one of their slogans, but not the-slogan.
I don't think so.
Now, that was - actually, that was their campaign slogan.
But their platform was to make New York City the 51st state.
But actually the slogan was vote the rascals in.
And he did finish, I think, fifth out of six, a Democrat running for mayor that year.
Larry(ph) in Amissville if I got that right or Amissville, Virginia says Norman Mailer or Jimmy Breslin campaigned to make New York City the 51st state so.
Thanks very much, John.
Congratulations.
What was William Buckley's reaction when they asked him what would you do if you won mayor?
When he ran for mayor of 1965, he said he would demand a recount.
Yes.
Which has always endeared him to me.
Thanks very much for the call, John.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Bye.
Let's go back to the question and go to - this is Wendy(ph), Wendy with us from Buffalo, New York.
Hi.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm well.
You're on the air.
Go ahead, please.
Okay.
I campaigned for Dennis Kucinich four years ago in Buffalo and we held a debate with the party representatives.
And I made some calls to Iowa back then.
And I'm making calls to Iowa now.

And I support Dennis wholeheartedly, and I will be disappointed if he's not our president because he is the only one who has the courage enough to tell everybody, nationally, publicly that he is planning to reform government.
And you would do this again, presumably, for either Mr. Kucinich or another candidate four years from now?
I would.
Uh-huh.
If I wholeheartedly believe in them.
And Dennis has integrity that is impeccable and that is in his record.
If you go to his Web site, there's a video on there when he was 31 years old and he was interviewed by Tom Snyder in a diner.
It's really, really amazing because he talked the same way he does now.
He has not changed and he has such staunch values and his platform has not changed.
He's still the same man.
